turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You're leaving it out. Finish your swing.  You're going to like this one -- she's half Asian, half American.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Good-looking?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: I just told you, she's half Asian. half American. They're all good looking. You could mate Don Rickles and Yoko Ono and they're going to have a gorgeous kid. It's a foolproof combo.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What's the point? Let's face it, Dom, I'm in a slump.  Lately I've been feeling like... well... like a loser.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Loser? You?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Give me a break. Remember five years ago, when your kidneys failed? If you were a loser would they have been able to find a donor with an exact tissue match? What are the odds of that, one in a million?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, so I'm lucky because my brother got killed in an explosion?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: I never said that. I'm saying your lucky those kids found his kidneys.  Besides, your brother Jimmy never gave a shit about you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It must be great with a wife like that.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Each day is better than the next.  Have you ever been, you know... in love with someone?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Never?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well once. Mary.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Mary again.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, I admit it was brief, but it was definitely love. Crushes don't last twelve years.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Whatever happened to Mary?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I told you, her family moved to Miami.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: I mean since then.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Well why don't you look her up?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, right.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Because I guarantee she's married and has a couple kids. Girls like Mary don't stay single.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: What if you're wrong? You just said she's the only girl you ever loved, what have you got to lose by calling her?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I did try calling her.  A few years ago. She wasn't listed.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: So that was it? One bump in the road and you gave up?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I also called Unsolved Mysteries.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You're kidding? What did they say?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: They told me they don't help out stalkers.  Look, maybe they're right, it's been a long time.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: I got it -- you hire a private eye, fly him out there, he follows her around a couple days, she'll never know a thing.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know about this, Dom.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Relax, this guy owes me a big one. A couple years ago he got in a jam up in the Boston office; some bullshit about padding his resume -- like we haven't all done that. Anyway, they were going to let him go but his mother wrote a tear-jerker letter that ended up on my desk.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: His mother?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Yeah, I guess he still lives with her. Seemed like a sweet lady -- got diabetes or something -- so I went out on a limb and got him transferred down to Providence.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And you think he could find out her number for me?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: He'll do better than that. I'll send him down to Miami on business, you throw him a couple bucks on the side, and he'll track her down.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's it, I'm making an oath. I'll never procrastinate about anything again. Life is too fucking short.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Hey, look on the bright side --

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What's that, Dom? What's the bright side?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Well... at least now you know.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I think it was better when I didn't. It was kind of inspiring to know there was someone so pure in the world.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What's so funny?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: I'm sorry, it's just that you're taking this all wrong, pal. Don't you see? You're liberated. I feel liberated. I mean here you've been in therapy thinking you blew it with the greatest girl ever, and it turns out that getting your dick stuck in your zipper was the best thing that ever happened to you!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wait a second, I never told you that.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Christ, Ted, I was only four towns away.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Maybe you're right. I should look on the bright side. I mean, I've still got my health...  I'm out of here. I've got to get up at six a.m. to move my boss's brother into his apartment.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: What? On your day off? Do you even know the guy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Never met him.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Jesus, Ted, you've got to finish that damn novel so you can quit that stupid magazine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Amen to that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary's a babe!

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: My Mary -- she's not in Japan, she's single, and she's got no rugrats. She does have a little gambling problem, she plays the football cards a bit too much, but she's a babe, a surgeon babe!

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Huh? But why did Healy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well think about it.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: No You mean...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: The lazy fuck just didn't bother to look her up.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That sneaky prick was probably practicing his jai alai.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Well then you've got to call her, man.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fuck calling her. I'm going down there.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You are one lucky sonofabitch, you know that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I am?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Didn't they tell you? That hitcher was just about to cut your throat when you stopped to take a leak. You got a fucking horseshoe up your ass, man.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah feels like it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How the hell did you get here anyway?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Flew.  Told my wife I was going to a Promise Keepers convention.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Shoot.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Remember our friend Healy? Well, I didn't know where to mail his last paycheck so I sent my assistant by his mother's apartment. Turns out there is no diabetic mom. Landlord said she's been dead for ten years.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And this adversely affects me how...?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Don't you see? -- Healy lied to us about everything! The landlord said when he got back from Miami he kept talking about falling for some doctor named Mary!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fuck me.  Let's go home.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: No! You've gone through way too much to back down now. Get over there and do something -- I can't stand watching this.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Well? What are you waiting for?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know what to say.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Tell her the truth about Healy! Blow the schmuck out of the water.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you crazy? I've unleashed a psycho on her. She's gonna be fucking pissed.  She's even more beautiful than I remember.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh God, I'm fucking nervous. I don't know if I'm ready for this, man.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Just relax. Have you hit the cash machine?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Got cash.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Car clean? Plenty of gas?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Mints?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Copped a tin of Altoids at the car wash.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Okay, sounds like you're all set. Just clean the pipes and it's a go.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You know, clean the pipes.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Pipes? What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You jerk off before all big dates, right? Tell me you jerk off before your big dates.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Think about it: After you've had sex with a girl and the two of you are laying in bed, are you nervous?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Why's that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm usually too tired to be.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Wrong. It's because you ain't got the baby batter in your brain any more. That'll fuck with your head, that stuff will.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: The most honest moment in a man's life is the five minutes after he's blown a load. That's a medical fact. And it's because you're no longer trying to get laid. You're actually thinking like a girl. They love that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jesus Christ you're right.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You bet your ass I'm right. You don't go out with a loaded gun, you empty the barrels!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Holy shit, I've been going out with a loaded gun!

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: People get hurt that way.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Dom? What are you?

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: You stole her from me. Now I want her back.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: Dom Wooganowski. Duh.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But but you're married. You have kids a great wife.

turns.speaker: DOM
turns.text: If you're so happy with them, please, be my guest.

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: So... I see you made the news.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It wasn't my truck -- I was helping out a guy in a wheelchair.

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: Uh-huh. Where was he?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Out getting coffee.

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: Yeah, that's more or less what the others said, too. Out getting coffee... supposed to meet him here... picking up my grandma...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Bob, do you remember Mary?

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary.

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: From high school Mary? Yeah, I saw her about six months ago at a convention in Las Vegas.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A convention? How'd you see her at a convention?

turns.speaker: DR. LALONDE
turns.text: I'm an orthopedic surgeon, she's an orthopedic surgeon.

turns.speaker: FRIEND #1
turns.text: Why don't you be a gentleman and ask Rosey?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: FRIEND #1
turns.text: Big guy -- goes to Barrington high school.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Woogie from Borrington high? Sounds like a loser.

turns.speaker: FRIEND #1
turns.text: Loser? Woogie was all-state football and and basketball and valedictorian of his class.

turns.speaker: FRIEND #1
turns.text: I got twenty bucks says you're full of shit.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh come on, why would I lie?

turns.speaker: FRIEND #1
turns.text: Because you're a loser, and in some warped way this gives you a momentary sense of worth.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: This is a good one, Mare. Sounds like his partner's all lubed up.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Call you back.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: You mean he doesn't like bad guys.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: 'That right?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: He can tell you're an animal nut. You are, aren't ya?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Truth is I usually get along better with animals than with people. In Nepal the villagers call me 'Kin-tan- tee', which means 'man who is loved by many animals...  ...who love him a lot, too... and so on.'

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Would you like a glass of tea or something?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You got a brew?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Would you like a little clam-dip, honey?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: No, thanks.  Love a little bundt cake if you have some!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: We're in love with your roommate.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Aw, Christ, I can't take it anymore. I'm gonna pack my bags and go back to my own place.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Healy you dog!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fucking Sully! Look at you!

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: You hot shit. Ya look fuckin' pisser.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Here's the info you asked for.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: You should thank me -- that girl was not easy to find. What'd she scam you out of-some insurance dough?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Nah, some guy threw me a few bucks to track down his high school girlfriend.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Stalker, huh?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Big time.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Very nice.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: I'm doing okay.  I gotta get ready for work.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Okay? With this pad, the killer wheels? Looks like you really cleaned up your act.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: What can I tell you? It's a healthier lifestyle down here, and it's easier to succeed when your head's clear. Those guys I worked with back in Boston, they were a bad influence.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fuckin' animals. Hey, what do you say we go grab a couple drinks.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Not for me, buddy. I don't drink anymore.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah, and you don't drink any less, right?

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Take it easy, that's Bill.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Tell Bill to get the fuck off!

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Relax, he just ate.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Nineteen months I been sober.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: What are you talking about? You were never an alky, you were a cokehead.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Yeah, well when you quit blow, you gotta quit the booze, too.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Is that right? Well good for you, Sull, I'm proud of you.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Here, just have one of these then.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Healy, what I just tell you?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: This is a light beer. You can't have a light beer?

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: No I can't.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I'm worried about you, man. You better learn to have a pop once in a while or you're gonna fall off the wagon. You're being a fanatic and that ain't healthy.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Am I?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Bet your ass you are. Now I don't want to hear anymore of your happy horseshit. You gotta learn how to bend a little or believe me... you're gonna break.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Jesus, you know what? This shit doesn't even taste good to me anymore.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ah, fuck ya then, you big pussy. What are you, spotting?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hello...? Sully...?  Sully, that you?

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Who the fuck is it to you?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Sully, it's Healy. What's going on over there?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Uh, I'm fine. Just wanted to let you know I'll have your car back in a couple hours, I'm still staking out this girl's apartment.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: You found my car?!

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: So where the hell are you, Healy?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ah, I got a date tonight with that Mary girl I told you about.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: The sawbones?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh yeah.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Dumbshit.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Why didn't you just tell her the truth?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I don't know. I guess... it just seems that women today are more impressed by the mighty buck than by some schmo who spent the last seventeen years scraping by on Peace Corp wages.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: But Jesus, Pat, if she's as special as you say, she's going to want to hear about the things you did.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ahh.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: The bottom line is, I'm not going to use my philanthropy as some form of currency... especially after what I did.  I lied to this poor girl. Lied, man. She deserved better.

turns.speaker: SULLY
turns.text: Hey, love will make you do fucked-up things.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You said it, mister.  I gotta go.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm just saying I don't mind a guy with a bit of a beer belly. It means he's a guy. You can have those pretty boys who hang out in a gym all day staring at their reflections.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: A girl after your own heart, Ted.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, don't talk in someone's backswing.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I'm gonna get a soda, you want one?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh cripes. Do you have change for a dollar? All I have is these stupid Nepalese coins.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nepal? Have you been?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Not in months. I don't even know why I bought the damn place.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You own a home there?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well... it's just a condo really. Right outside Katmandu.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Wow. That's a place I've always wanted to go. Is it true the mountains are so tall you can't see the tops?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Not 'til you get about three hundred yards from the summit. That's been my experience anyway.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Here. Spend it on your trip to Katmandu.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, it was nice meeting you, again.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Same here again.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: By the way, what's your name?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Pat Healy.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't you want to know my name?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I already know it, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How'd you know that?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: It's right there on your golf bag.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What are you doing with all these blueprints?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Some buildings I'm working on.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Are you... an architect?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well, just until I get my PGA Tour card.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I'm kidding. Yeah, I guess you could call me an architect -- it's just a job really, a way to keep me moving. My real passion is my hobby.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I work with retards.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You know...  ...the guys who ride the short bus.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Isn't that a little politically incorrect?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: The hell with that. No one's gonna tell me who I can and can't work with.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, I mean

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: -- There's this one kid, we call him Mongo on account of he's a mongoloid. He got out of his cage once and --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: -- He's in a cage?!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well it's more of an enclosure really.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: They keep him confined? That's bullshit!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That's what I said, so I went out and got him a leash you know, one of those clothesline runners for the backyard. He's got plenty of room out there to dig. The kid's really blossomed. Now I can take him to ball games, movies -- you know, happy stuff.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That sounds like fun.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah, it's fun for them, but it's heaven for me.  Those goofy bastards are just about the best thing I have in this crazy old world.  Ooh, hey, I gotta run.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Look, uh, I was thinking maybe we should go have dinner sometime.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh, Pufferball likes his little tum- tum rubbed, doesn't he now?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Wow, I've never seen him like this. He doesn't usually like guys.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sorry, Pat, out of beer. You like vodka?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fine. Fine.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Here you go.  What's that smell?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: The museum? I thought we were going out to dinner?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We will, but first I have a surprise.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: A surprise?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: The architecture exhibit! My friend Tucker is going to be here. He's an architect, too. You guys will have tons to talk about.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I know he's around here someplace.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: What say we get outta here and go crush a bucket?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We just got here thirty seconds ago. Isn't this stuff great?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is this one art deco or art nouveau?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Deco.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would you call that a portico or a vestibule?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That...? Vestibule.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How about -- ?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: When you look at architecture, try not to concern yourself with the pieces -- look at the building in its totalitarianism.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That grandmother of yours -- she's really something.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Magda? She's not my grandmother -- actually she rents the apartment right next to mine. Her husband passed away a couple years ago so she doesn't like to be alone.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: And it doesn't cramp your style?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sadly, no. Well except for the lint.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Lint?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, I think it's that dog of hers running around on the rug all day -- just makes for a lot of lint. Look at this...

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You know, sometimes I wish I could be like Magda and not go home. I'd like to just bounce around for awhile, do a little traveling...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why bounce when you have your own condo in Nepal to go to?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ah, I'd sell that. Start fresh in a new place, quit the architect game, slow things down, read more books, see more movies...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You're a movie buff?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Try to be. It's tough going with the crap they make today. If Dumb and Dumber's the best they've got to offer I say thanks but no thanks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Have you seen it?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: No. But the Boston Globe critic Jay Carr hated it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: A fucking moron.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Huh. I guess I just wish they made them like they used to. You know, something like The Heartbreak Kid... or Harold and Maude.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Harold and Maude is my all-time favorite movie.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ouch. Come on, don't bust my chops. I know it's corny, but I do love it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Pat, I'm not kidding. I really think it's the greatest --

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: -- Love story of our time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Wow. I thought I was the only one.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So...

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah... I guess this is it, huh?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well, I'll see ya.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Mary ah, forget it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: No, forget it, it was stupid.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Come on, what were you going to say?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Nah, really, it was moronic.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fuck!!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Huh... that's strange.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Turn it up, Magda.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hey, watch your mouth -- she's a great gal. I'm the dumbshit for lying to her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All set.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You look great.  Hey, Mare, do I have a rip in the back of these pants?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: How's my stomach taste, she says.  Hey thanks for picking up the lunch tab, Mare. Sorry I forgot my wallet. I feel like a dog.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Forget it. It was... fun.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Urrggghh...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Warren!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Not to worry. So... see you tonight, right? Right?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We're gonna go out tonight. Oh, that reminds me, I've got to call what's- his-face and cancel.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hi, I'm out drinking champagne and roses... and I'm really happy. Leave a message. BEEP.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Uh, hey buddy. Oh boy, am I pissed. You're not going to believe this -- well, you'll believe it, there's no reason not to -- but I just got beeped for emergency surgery. Well, um, sorry, but I'm going to have to bail on you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Woogie, please, you're starting to scare me.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Who the hell's Woogie?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I say none of us leave this room until our young Mary here stops jerking us around and decides once and for all who she wants. Now Mary, I know this is difficult but you really will be doing them all a favor to tell them the truth about us.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Are you crazy? Why would I pick you? You're a murderer.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: So, Dom tells me you're looking for some lady-friend you knew in high school.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Any idea where I might start looking?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: She moved to Miami Beach twelve years ago. I checked directory assistance down there and she's not listed. She might've moved ten times since then.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: All you want is a phone number?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, I know you're busy...

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Don't play games with me, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know, maybe you could poke around for a half day and see if she has five kids and a Labrador.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I don't buy it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You don't buy what?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ted, I'm the kind of guy who shoots from the hip. Now I want you to level with me: Did you knock this skirt up?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: She's blackmailing you, right?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You want her dead, don't you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You can't be serious.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Do you really expect me to believe this is a straight stalker case?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm not a stalker! She's a friend of mine.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Sure she is. That's why she got an unlisted number and you haven't heard squat from her in a dozen years. Oh you're good, Ted. You're a real piece of work.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, let's forget it. Let's forget the whole thing.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I get one hundred a day plus expenses.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You get fifty a day, period. It's a business trip, they'll pay for your expenses.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I've got some very, very good news for you, my friend.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really?  Very, very?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I think your life's about to change.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So you found Mary?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Right there in Liberty City. And you were right, she's really something.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So she hasn't changed?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That I couldn't say. Let me ask you something: Was she a little big-boned in high school?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, not at all.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well she must've packed on a few pounds over the years.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary's a little chubby, huh?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I'd say about a deuce, deuce and a half. Not bad.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: But you know, you shit out a bunch of kids, you're going to put on a few pounds.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So she's married?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Nope. Never been.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Four kids, three different guys.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Three different guys?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well I'm guessing. There's a black kid, two whites, and a midget.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh my.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hyperactive little fuckers, too. Tough to keep up with in a wheelchair, I bet.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: She's in a wheelchair?!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Don't look so shocked, it's been a long time. I bet you've changed a lot over the last twelve years, haven't you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's just that... Mary. I wouldn't have thought...

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Anyway, the good news is I have all the information you need. Got it from her bookie -- nice guy. You should definitely call her, Ted. I mean she's a real sparkplug, that one. She seems determined to get those rugrats off welfare and with your help I'll bet she does it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thanks, Healy. Good work.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ted? Don't you want the name of the housing project?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, that's okay.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You sure, big guy? I'll bet she'd love to hear from you before her mastectomy!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh, uh, I resigned.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Miami?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah, this insurance business is too slow for me. I'm going to go down and try my hand at jai alai.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jai alai?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah, I don't know why but I always felt at home in the fronton.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, uh, I've been thinking about everything you told me.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Good good.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well I think you're right, I should look her up.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Rollerpig? Are you nuts?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But you said she was a sparkplug...?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I said buttplug. She's heinous.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All the same, I still want to call her. I know it sounds crazy -- Mary sure has a lot of troubles in her life -- but, I don't know, maybe I can help her out.  The poor thing's had it tough -- she's in a wheelchair for Godsakes.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: It's a goddamn bunion. It'll heal.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh. I thought  That's not it anyway. I know this doesn't make any sense to you, but I just can't turn it off that fast. I still feel something for her.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Okay, tell you what: I'll get her number for you just as soon as she gets back from Japan.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Japan? What's she doing in Japan?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You've heard of mail-order brides? Well they go that way, too.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary's a mail-order bride?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fetched a pretty penny, too. Don't forget, it's the Sumo culture, they pay by the pound there. Sort of like tuna.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hey, hey, hey!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Surprised?
